concept.title: Introducing DITA
concept.shortdesc: DITA is the Darwin Information Typing Architecture, which supports authoring of information-typed topics for task-oriented information sets.

conbody.p: DITA supports creation and management of information-typed topics, which can be linked and assembled together using DITA maps into online help, information centers, or PDFs. DITA topics and maps can also be reused in IBMIDDoc documents. DITA provides four types of topic to start: concept topics, task topics, reference topics, and, when those don't apply, an untyped generic topic. You can supplement the information type with additional information about a topic's intended audience and subject area or product.

When you author content using DITA, you will find the experience to be somewhat different than authoring in HTML or IBMIDDoc. The following are some key characteristics of the DITA authoring experience:

dlentry.dd: The topic is the smallest independently maintainable unit of content. Topics must be able to stand alone so that they can be reused and recombined in various presentation media (online help and an information center, for example).
Information types provide a way to identify each topic as either a task, concept, or reference topic. You can also use generic topics when the existing information types don't apply.

Using DITA metadata elements, you can identify topic content according to audience, product name, brand, and platform, among other categories. You can then filter or flag the content to customize it for particular product deliverables and audiences.
DITA supports writing separate topics for maximum reuse. You can also author a group of topics together in one file, if a set of topics needs to always be kept together as a unit.

DITA output is customizable. When the default output from your content is inappropriate for your users' needs or product branding requirements, you can override the treatment of particular elements or categories of content. This lets you concentrate on using the markup accurately, instead of choosing markup for formatting effects.
